8/ To convince S&P-bm’d mgrs to buy $TSLA initially or to add to positions, need following:
1) Huge FY’21 deliv guide causing buy side ests to rise sharply
2) Biden EV/clean energy platform far broader than expected
3) Big increase in TSLA price, causing PMs to fear career risk

7/ IMO, few active mgrs with S&P bms have closed their $TSLA underweight positions:
1) Trend to more concentrated (30-50 name) portfolios, so fewer names held as bm weights.
2) Prevailing view after 720% gain in 2020, TSLA due for a pullback
3) Looks expensive on 2021 P/E (200x+)

6/ Every day, PMs gets emails showing daily and YTD performance vs bm, w/largest contributors and detractors of performance. With $TSLA +17% and S&P +0.3% YTD, a PM with zero TSLA weight (vs 1.9% bm) would see TSLA as a -32 bp detractor - fairly large just two wks into the year.

5/ Active PMs at large shops get paid a nominal base salary plus an annual bonus generally tied to 1- and 3-yr performance vs peers and vs bms. The bonus can be 1-10x salary. The difference b/t 1st quartile and 4th quartile performance can be huge. $tsla

4/ The analyst puts together a 1-2 page reco w/ growth and valuation metrics, attaches a model, and presents it to the PMs. If a PM wants to buy $TSLA, they tell the trader to start a position at some weight. There’s no deadline or pressure other than risk of underperformance.

3/ I believe the buying that has pushed $TSLA +17% YTD is from three sources:
1) Active mgrs w/ S&P bms
2) Shorts hedging next few wks
3) Traders speculating on 4Q EPS beat/FY’21 volume guide

At an active shop like Fidelity or TROW, the investment process is as follows....

2/ Many of these active S&P-bm’d mgrs with $8T AUM are core/value mgrs, who can’t stomach $TSLA at 200x Street 2021 P/E. Still, at a 1.9% bm, these funds need 184M shares (24% float) to be equal weight. With TSLA +720% in 2020 and +17% 2021 YTD, pressure to own some TSLA is high.

The Goldman study of large cap mutual funds bm’d to S&P 500 found that 17% (32 of 189) held $TSLA as of Sept 30. Unlike the S&P inclusion event, there’s no rule that the 83% not owning TSLA have to own it. The risk of underperforming one’s BM or peer group is a big 2021 catalyst.
